newsitem.title: UKRAINE: Songs, protests mark year of Ukraine constitution.
newsitem.headline: Songs, protests mark year of Ukraine constitution.

text.p: Ukraine marked the first anniversary of its post-Soviet constitution with a leftist protest, Italian arias and a sea of blue-and-yellow national flags on Saturday.
About 5,000 people, many of them pensioners hobbling with the aid of walking sticks, proceeded along Kiev's main street Khreshchatyk shouting "Down with the president!".
Their red banners clashed with official national flags lining the street where mass protests heralded independence from Moscow and the end of the Soviet Union in 1991.
Nostalgic Soviet songs filled the air, at times drowned out by Italian arias being sung at official events on nearby Maidan Nezalezhnosti (Independence Square) nearby.
They were protesting at living conditions, which for many have worsened despite economic reforms, and the constitution, passed by parliament a year ago and promising rights for all.
"To hell with your prostitution constitution!" yelled a woman in her 60s in a floppy yellow and white cotton hat.
Parliamentary Speaker Olexander Moroz, a socialist, urged the crowd to vote for the left at elections due next March.
He said deputies would not back President Leonid Kuchma if he tried to extend their term by a year, a move Kuchma said he was considering at a concert in Kiev's Opera House on Friday.
Such a move is not allowed under the constitution unless it wins approval from two-thirds of the left-dominated parliament.
Kuchma launched reforms in 1994 but a mountain of unpaid wages and pensions regularly brings workers onto the streets. Saturday's protest was led by the Ukrainian Workers' Union.
Two women bashed saucepans together, chanting: "Fat cats! Fat cats!" as they passed some of the expensive shops which have sprung up in central Kiev since independence.
Protesters and bystanders pointed to their heads to show they thought the other side was crazy.

A shrunken man in his 80s urged an equally shrunken woman of about the same age to join the protest. But she told him: "You want Kuchma to resign, but someone just as bad will come in his place. They're all former Communists, each one as bad the next".
"You are living in a free, independent country!" a man in his 50s screamed as a new chant of "Soviet Union" began.
Ukraine has received billions of dollars in loans and aid from the West, especially Washington which has a strategic interest in strengthening Kiev's independence from Moscow.
But reforms are sluggish, privatisation has proceeded at a snail's pace and widespread government corruption in the country of 51 million is a problem acknowledged even by Kuchma.
A woman in her early 20s, taken aback by the protest, argued with her grandmother on the pavement. "But the Soviet Union did not let us live," she said.
Memories are still strong in Ukraine of decades of Soviet repression, especially an artificial famine in the early 1930s caused by the policies of dictator Josef Stalin.
Stalin's aim was to wipe out powerful landowners and bearers of national sentiment in rural, agricultural communities. More than seven million people starved to death.
